Award.AwardTitle: Microbial platforms and tools for benzylisoquinoline alkaloid biosynthesis

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: This NSF award by the Biotechnology, Biochemical and Biomass Engineering program supports work to develop novel engineering approaches for natural product synthesis. The engineering of biosynthetic pathways in microbial hosts represents a newer approach to chemical synthesis with exciting potential. While traditional approaches to engineering cellular biosynthesis processes require a significant investment of time and resources that does not scale with the complexity represented in many natural product biosynthesis schemes, recent advances in synthetic biology are transforming the complexity of genetic networks that can be engineered in biological systems. The goal of this research is to develop a microbial biosynthesis platform for an important class of natural products, the benzylisoquinoline alkaloids (BIAs). The investigators will utilize this microbial platform to broadly advance scalable biosynthesis strategies for complex natural products and provide insights into nature's own biosynthetic strategies. Specifically, the investigators propose to: (i) construct synthetic pathways for the biosynthesis of early BIAs from amino acid precursors; (ii) develop insulation strategies for the synthetic BIA pathway through modification of native yeast pathways; (iii) develop strategies for organelle routing for biosynthesis specialization and compartmentalization; (iv) link optimized BIA branches for the total synthesis of specialty BIAs; (v) develop new biological engineering curriculum that emphasizes foundational concepts in synthetic biology and integrated systems design strategies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF award has funded research that has led to the development of new tools for engineering yeast-based processes for producing valuable plant natural products. In particular, yeast strains have been engineered that overproduce key precursors and produce key advanced intermediates to many valuable plant compounds and compounds derived from plant natural products. These yeast strains will serve as valuable platforms for the further engineering of yeast that can make high-value plant-derived compounds through efficient microbial fermentation processes.

            The research conducted under this award also resulted in a number of new molecular tools to support the engineering of complex biosynthetic pathways in yeast-based hosts. In particular, an organelle routing toolkit was developed that allows reliable localization of heterologous proteins to distinct organelles in the yeast cell. Tags were developed and validated that can direct proteins to distinct subcellular compartments and direct the presentation of the proteins (e.g., facing into the cytosol or into the lumen of the organelle). These tools have been used to incorporate engineered spatial localization strategies into these complex biosynthetic pathways, and provide an important tool for optimizing pathway activity and specificity.

            More broadly, the research conducted under this award has greatly advanced the complexity of biosynthetic pathways that can be engineered into a simple microorganism like yeast; representing a key milestone for the field. The research highlights the value of yeast-based platforms for making a diversity of valuable and complex molecules and chemicals, particularly those that were previously thought to be limited to synthesis in plant hosts. With further development the outcomes of this award will allow for new strategies for drug discovery, development, and manufacturing, and will also advance strategies for pathway discovery.

            There are a number of outcomes of this award that have broader impacts beyond the research reported. For example, four new bioengineering courses were developed and refined over the course of this award. These courses spanned both lecture and laboratory courses and were targeted to undergraduates early in their career, advanced undergraduates, and graduate students. These courses incorporated cutting-edge content and techniques from bioengineering and were developed to incorporate open-ended design problems that encouraged the students to work in teams to tackle challenging problems, which is a critical skill for engineering students to learn. These courses are now part of the core bioengineering curriculum at Stanford’s Bioengineering Department.

            In addition, the award has supported the training of several graduate student researchers and numerous undergraduate student researchers. Most of the undergraduates have gone on to further their training in graduate school and the graduate students have gone on to startup companies in biotech industry. There are a couple patents that have been filed based on the outcomes of this award. These patents have been licensed by a startup company that will focus on commercializing the developed technologies. The translation of these technologies into industry will lead to many jobs being created for scientists and engineers and will have broader impact on society as the technology is deployed to make and fairly provide medicines to all who need them.
